newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Asia stocks buoyed by Fed policy, foreign funds.
newsitem.headline: Asia stocks buoyed by Fed policy, foreign funds.

text.p: Asian stock markets gained almost across the board on Wednesday, boosted by the Fed's decision to leave U.S. interest rates unchanged and a return of foreign funds.
Seoul was a rare faller and dropped 0.60 percent as persistent worries on the economy overshadowed the market.
Tokyo stocks ended higher for the third straight day, relieved by the U.S. Federal Reserve's decision to leave interest rates steady.
But brokers said the market lacked energy to test higher levels.
The key 225-share Nikkei average closed up 148.01 points, or 0.70 percent, at 21,275.02, off a high of 21,391.00 set earlier in the day. Its September futures gained 80 points to 21,260.
"One of the drags on the market has disappeared," said Haruo Nakaharu, a strategist at Toyo Securities Co Ltd. He was referring to Tuesday's Federal Open Market Committee meeting.
Hong Kong stocks ended the session sharply higher as the Fed's decision to leave interest rates unchanged boosted market sentiment.

The Hang Seng index rose 123.99 points, or 1.10 percent, to 11,436.50. Turnover soared to HK$5.88 billion from HK$3.44 billion on Tuesday. Index constituents HSBC Holdings and CITIC Pacific both hit record highs.

"No interest rate rise in the U.S. improved sentiment a bit further and high market liqidity also gave the sign that some overseas funds are coming into the market," said Ben Kwong, director of research at Dharmala Securities.
Jakarta shares closed higher on the back of bargain-hunting in selected big-capitalised stocks and secondliners.
The Jakarta composite index rose 2.60 points, or 0.48 percent, to 542.20 points.
Singapore's Straits Times Industrials Index surged 31.79 points, or 1.50 percent, to 2,155.60.
The gain was linked to advances in second line stocks and modest gains for blue chips.
Kuala Lumpur's Composite Index gained 17.38 points to 1,122.82 as blue chips surged on renewed institutional buying.
Thai stocks rose 2.01 percent as the entry of a market support fund boosted confidence and investors bought bank and finance issues, brokers said.
The SET index closed 23.62 points up at 1,095.03.
The South Korean bourse ended at a new 33-month low, dragged down by worries about the economy's health.
The composite stock index fell 4.79 points to close provisionally at 789.12.
Manila shares sprang out of the the doldrums after the return of foreign funds as the U.S. Fed left interest rates unchanged.
The main index rallied 20.87 points to 3,111.56 after Tuesday's 1.98 point drop.

The Australian share market, the day afer the country's ight 1996/97 budget, rallied in line with futures and bonds markets after Standard and Poor's revised Australia's credit outlook to positive from stable.
The All Ordinaries index rose 21.3 points to 2,286.0.
Strong buying in shipping stocks pushed Taiwan share prices to a sharply higher close, one day after China issued rules governing direct shipping links with the island.
The weighted index shot up 120.34 points, or 1.99 percent, to finish at 6,177.78.
In Bombay, foreign funds and local institutions drove the benchmark index up 90.27 points to 3,406.33.
In late Tokyo trade, the dollar was at 108.34/39 yen and 1.4848/53 marks, against New York's Tuesday close of 108.31/36 yen and 1.4891/96 marks.
On SIMEX, October Brent futures were traded at $20.35 in late business, down 12 cents from London's Tuesday settlement.
Bullion ended at US$387.30/80 an ounce in Hong Kong, little changed on Tuesday's New York's close of $387.50/388.00.
